issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

fields.description:
Content needed in 4.2.0 Release Notes and User Guide.

Since the introduction of the OSG component for S3 API, we have allowed the continued use of 'walrus' for a dns service name that resolved to the OSG. This was a legacy fix to avoid breaking clients and forcing an immediate change to 'objectstorage', which is the proper DNS name for the service now (Walrus is an internal component, not user facing).

In 4.2.0 we are removing that legacy mapping, so 'walrus.mycloud.com' will no longer resolve to the OSG components. To use DNS for S3 API with Eucalyptus the 'objectstorage' subdomain must be used.
fields.summary: 'walrus' as DNS name for object storage removed in 4.2.0. Use only 'objectstorage'

comments.body: [~scottb] just happened to see this that we missed for 4.2. Can you add it to the 4.2.1 release notes? (is this a known issue? where would we put this?)

[~sjones] Please confirm that these are all OK and if there's another place to correct that I have not spotted, let me know.

1. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#shared/setting_up_dns.html shows:
{code}For example, the bucket mybucket is accessible as mybucket.objectstorage.mycloud.example.com.{code}
... which I believe is now correct?

2. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#iam-guide/access_policy_algorithms.html example at bottom of the page includes walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb property, which I assume is fine.
3. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_imgs_win.html shows 5 occurrences of walrus.storagesomethingorother properties, which I assume are fine.
4. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#image-guide/img_task_remove_image.html shows walrus.storagedir property, which I assume is fine.

[~kmeredith], I think the walrus DNS name change was reverted so it can still be used (but it is deprecated so we should not be documenting it)

There are no properties starting with "walrus.", any references should be updated to the new component name (walrusbackend):

{code}
# euctl walrus
walrusbackend.blockdevice = 
walrusbackend.resource = 
walrusbackend.storagedir = //var/lib/eucalyptus/bukkits
walrusbackend.storagemaxtotalcapacity = 0
{code}
Thanks, [~sjones]. So I think that means #1 is OK and 2,3,4 need to be updated to walrusbackend. Please confirm I got that right.

[~kmeredith], the walrus component is now internal (which is why it is now called walrusbackend), so any reference to walrus when discussing DNS should likely be changed to objectstorage. Any reference to a "walrus." property is incorrect as these properties no longer exist.

OK thank you [~sjones]. That changes this ticket's scope a bit - very good to fix the docs!

[~swathi] can you please verify these changes: 

1. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#shared/setting_up_dns.html shows:
{code}For example, the bucket mybucket is accessible as mybucket.objectstorage.mycloud.example.com.{code}
... I believe is correct *please confirm*

2. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#iam-guide/access_policy_algorithms.html
updated walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb to walrusbackend.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb
... which appears here:
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/4.2.1/#iam-guide/access_policy_algorithms.html
*please confirm correct*

3. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_imgs_win.html - 
a. updated walrus.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb to walrusbackend.storagemaxbucketsizeinmb *please confirm*
b. updated walrus.storagemaxtotalsnapshotsizeingb to walrusbackend.storagemaxtotalsnapshotsizeingb *please confirm*
... which appears here:
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/4.2.1/#troubleshooting-guide/ts_imgs_win.html
c. *Question:* it appears that storagemaxcachesizeinmb property was removed in Zach's 3/2014 commit:
{quote}walrus.storagemaxcachesizeinmb: total size of all images that is cached in Walrus; should be larger than the sum of all images (Windows/Linux) in Walrus{quote} *should I delete the bullet? or is there a replacement?*

4. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#image-guide/img_task_remove_image.html
updated walrus.storagedir to walrusbackend.storageDir
... which appears here:
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/4.2.1/#image-guide/img_task_remove_image.html
*please confirm correct*

5. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#euca2ools-guide/euca_conf.html
updated --register-walrus to --register-walrusbackend
updated --deregister-walrus to --deregister-walrusbackend
updated --list-walruses to --list-walrusbackends
... which appears here:
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/documentation/origin/4.2.1/#euca2ools-guide/euca_conf.html
*please confirm correct*

6. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#admin-guide/system_concepts.html
includes a description of Walrus that is very likely out of date. *Who can help me update this description?*

7. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#admin-guide/manage_resources_walrus.html
*Is this section still accurate?*

8. http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#shared/osg_accessing.html
*Is this section still accurate?*

PS [~swathi] if you are not the correct person to ask, please let me know ASAP.
[~lincoln.thomas]: Can you please take a look at the above questions and provide information?
[~lincoln.thomas] please let me know if you spot any errors or omissions. thanks!
Re-assigning back to [~swathi] per discussion with her.
[~lincoln.thomas], in WalrusInfo the configurable items are the ones annotated with @ConfigurableField. Some properties were removed in the fix for EUCA-8933.

Ok thanks [~sjones]. So [~kmeredith] I guess that means you get to remove everything in the docs about all those fields! The only configurable ones are the 4 in that short list from the "euctl walrus" output. For both 4.2.2 and 4.3.

[~kmeredith]: Here's the remaining feedback.

6. That whole section http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#admin-guide/system_concepts.html should be superseded by the better equivalent http://docs.hpcloud.com/eucalyptus/4.2.1/#install-guide/euca_components.html. Even so, there should also be a description of what object storage is. In the OSG section, you could add something like this at the beginning (some of this drawn from the old/bad page in the admin guide):

Object storage allows users to store persistent data, organized as buckets and objects. You can use object storage to create, delete, and list buckets, or to put, get, and delete objects, or to set access control policies. Object storage is interface compatible with Amazonâ€™s Simple Storage Service (S3). You can access it from client machines outside the cloud or from virtual machine instance running inside the cloud. Object storage is also used by Eucalyptus internally for storing virtual machine images. 

Object storage is comprised of two components: The Object Storage Gateway (OSG) and the Object Storage Provider (OSP). The OSG ... (existing text).

7. Yes it's still correct, just replace "Walrus" with "Object Storage".

8. On the parent page "Using Object Storage", replace "object storage backend" with "object storage provider".
Replace "s3curl" with "s3cmd" in this page and the "Access Object Storage" page.. The "s3curl" tool is a touchy subject because Eucalyptus has its own fork of the one contributed by someone in the AWS community (not an Amazon tool), and the community tool won't always work against Eucalyptus, where our fork of s3curl will. The s3cmd tool is a common AWS community tool and works against Eucalyptus just fine (AFAIK).
Everything after "To access object storage:" is outdated and now wrong (including the Note). Replace it with something like:

When you create a credentials file, for example using the euare-useraddkey CLI command, it will contain a line such as:
s3-url = http://s3.host1.mycompany.com:8773/
You can access object storage from your tools or APIs using this URL, or the equivalent URL:
http://objectstorage.host1.mycompany.com:8773
If you do not have DNS enabled on your cloud, you can instead access object storage by the IP address of the UFS host, with the object storage service suffix, for example:
http://203.0.113.1:8773/services/objectstorage
Performing an HTTP GET on this URL will return the list of buckets. To access a specific bucket by name, you can add it as a prefix to the DNS-enabled URL, or as a suffix to the IP URL, as in:
http://mybucket.s3.host1.mycompany.com:8773/
http://mybucket.objectstorage.host1.mycompany.com:8773/
http://203.0.113.1:8773/services/objectstorage/mybucket
